packageMeta.name: purescript-behaviors
packageMeta.description: A simple implementation of FRP which separates events and behaviors

declarations.comments:
`ABehavior` is the more general type of `Behavior`, which is parameterized
over some underlying `event` type.

Normally, you should use `Behavior` instead, but this type
can also be used with other types of events, including the ones in the
`Semantic` module.
declarations.title: ABehavior

declarations.comments:
A `Behavior` acts like a continuous function of time.

We can construct a sample a `Behavior` from some `Event`, combine `Behavior`s
using `Applicative`, and sample a final `Behavior` on some other `Event`.
declarations.title: Behavior

declarations.comments: Construct a `Behavior` from its sampling function.
declarations.title: behavior

declarations.comments:
Create a `Behavior` which is updated when an `Event` fires, by providing
an initial value.
declarations.title: step

declarations.comments:
Create a `Behavior` which is updated when an `Event` fires, by providing
an initial value and a function to combine the current value with a new event
to create a new value.
declarations.title: unfold

declarations.comments: Sample a `Behavior` on some `Event`.
declarations.title: sample

declarations.comments: Sample a `Behavior` on some `Event` by providing a combining function.
declarations.title: sampleBy

declarations.comments: Sample a `Behavior` on some `Event`, discarding the event's values.
declarations.title: sample_

declarations.comments: Switch `Behavior`s based on an `Event`.
declarations.title: switcher

declarations.comments: Sample a `Behavior` on some `Event` by providing a predicate function.
declarations.title: gateBy

declarations.comments: Filter an `Event` by the boolean value of a `Behavior`.
declarations.title: gate

declarations.comments:
Integrate with respect to some measure of time.

This function approximates the integral using the trapezium rule at the
implicit sampling interval.

The `Semiring` `a` should be a vector field over the field `t`. To represent
this, the user should provide a _grate_ which lifts a multiplication
function on `t` to a function on `a`. Simple examples where `t ~ a` can use
the `integral'` function instead.
declarations.title: integral

declarations.comments:
Integrate with respect to some measure of time.

This function is a simpler version of `integral` where the function being
integrated takes values in the same field used to represent time.
declarations.title: integral'

declarations.comments:
Differentiate with respect to some measure of time.

This function approximates the derivative using a quotient of differences at the
implicit sampling interval.

The `Semiring` `a` should be a vector field over the field `t`. To represent
this, the user should provide a grate which lifts a division
function on `t` to a function on `a`. Simple examples where `t ~ a` can use
the `derivative'` function.
declarations.title: derivative

declarations.comments:
Differentiate with respect to some measure of time.

This function is a simpler version of `derivative` where the function being
differentiated takes values in the same field used to represent time.
declarations.title: derivative'

declarations.comments: Compute a fixed point
declarations.title: fixB

declarations.comments:
Solve a first order differential equation of the form

```
da/dt = f a
```

by integrating once (specifying the initial conditions).

For example, the exponential function with growth rate `⍺`:

```purescript
exp = solve' 1.0 Time.seconds (⍺ * _)
```
declarations.title: solve

declarations.comments:
Solve a first order differential equation.

This function is a simpler version of `solve` where the function being
integrated takes values in the same field used to represent time.
declarations.title: solve'

declarations.comments:
Solve a second order differential equation of the form

```
d^2a/dt^2 = f a (da/dt)
```

by integrating twice (specifying the initial conditions).

For example, an (damped) oscillator:

```purescript
oscillate = solve2' 1.0 0.0 Time.seconds (\x dx -> -⍺ * x - δ * dx)
```
declarations.title: solve2

declarations.comments:
Solve a second order differential equation.

This function is a simpler version of `solve2` where the function being
integrated takes values in the same field used to represent time.
declarations.title: solve2'

declarations.comments: Animate a `Behavior` by providing a rendering function.
declarations.title: animate

declarations.comments: A `Behavior` which reports the keys which are currently pressed.
declarations.title: keys

declarations.comments: A `Behavior` which reports whether a specific key is currently pressed.
declarations.title: key

declarations.comments: A `Behavior` which reports the current mouse position, if it is known.
declarations.title: position

declarations.comments: A `Behavior` which reports the mouse buttons which are currently pressed.
declarations.title: buttons

declarations.comments: Get the current time in milliseconds since the epoch.
declarations.title: millisSinceEpoch

declarations.comments: Get the current time in seconds since the epoch.
declarations.title: seconds

declarations.comments:
`Filterable` represents data structures which can be _partitioned_/_filtered_.

- `partitionMap` - partition a data structure based on an either predicate.
- `partition` - partition a data structure based on boolean predicate.
- `filterMap` - map over a data structure and filter based on a maybe.
- `filter` - filter a data structure based on a boolean.

Laws:
- `map f ≡ filterMap (Just <<< f)`
- `filter ≡ filterMap <<< maybeBool`
- `filterMap p ≡ filter (isJust <<< p)`

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `partitionDefault`
- `partitionDefaultFilter`
- `partitionDefaultFilterMap`
- `filterDefault`
- `filterDefaultPartition`
- `filterDefaultPartitionMap`
declarations.title: Filterable

declarations.comments:
Functions which an `Event` type should implement, so that
`Behavior`s can be defined in terms of any such event type:

- `fold`: combines incoming values using the specified function,
starting with the specific initial value.
- `keepLatest` flattens a nested event, reporting values only from the
most recent inner event.
- `sampleOn`: samples an event at the times when a second event fires.
- `fix`: compute a fixed point, by feeding output events back in as
inputs.
declarations.title: IsEvent

declarations.comments: Compute differences between successive event values.
declarations.title: withLast

declarations.comments:
Create an `Event` which samples the latest values from the first event
at the times when the second event fires, ignoring the values produced by
the second event.
declarations.title: sampleOn_

declarations.comments:
Map over an event with an accumulator.

For example, to keep the index of the current event:

```purescript
mapAccum (\x i -> Tuple (i + 1) (Tuple x i)) 0`.
```
declarations.title: mapAccum

declarations.comments: Combine subsequent events using a `Monoid`.
declarations.title: folded

declarations.comments: Count the number of events received.
declarations.title: count

declarations.comments:
An `Event` represents a collection of discrete occurrences with associated
times. Conceptually, an `Event` is a (possibly-infinite) list of values-and-times:

```purescript
type Event a = List { value :: a, time :: Time }
```

Events are created from real events like timers or mouse clicks, and then
combined using the various functions and instances provided in this module.

Events are consumed by providing a callback using the `subscribe` function.
declarations.title: Event

declarations.comments:
Subscribe to an `Event` by providing a callback.

`subscribe` returns a canceller function.
declarations.title: subscribe

declarations.comments:
`Filterable` represents data structures which can be _partitioned_/_filtered_.

- `partitionMap` - partition a data structure based on an either predicate.
- `partition` - partition a data structure based on boolean predicate.
- `filterMap` - map over a data structure and filter based on a maybe.
- `filter` - filter a data structure based on a boolean.

Laws:
- `map f ≡ filterMap (Just <<< f)`
- `filter ≡ filterMap <<< maybeBool`
- `filterMap p ≡ filter (isJust <<< p)`

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `partitionDefault`
- `partitionDefaultFilter`
- `partitionDefaultFilterMap`
- `filterDefault`
- `filterDefaultPartition`
- `filterDefaultPartitionMap`
declarations.title: Filterable

declarations.comments:
Functions which an `Event` type should implement, so that
`Behavior`s can be defined in terms of any such event type:

- `fold`: combines incoming values using the specified function,
starting with the specific initial value.
- `keepLatest` flattens a nested event, reporting values only from the
most recent inner event.
- `sampleOn`: samples an event at the times when a second event fires.
- `fix`: compute a fixed point, by feeding output events back in as
inputs.
declarations.title: IsEvent

declarations.comments: Count the number of events received.
declarations.title: count

declarations.comments: Combine subsequent events using a `Monoid`.
declarations.title: folded

declarations.comments: Compute differences between successive event values.
declarations.title: withLast

declarations.comments:
Map over an event with an accumulator.

For example, to keep the index of the current event:

```purescript
mapAccum (\x i -> Tuple (i + 1) (Tuple x i)) 0`.
```
declarations.title: mapAccum

declarations.comments:
Create an `Event` which samples the latest values from the first event
at the times when the second event fires, ignoring the values produced by
the second event.
declarations.title: sampleOn_

declarations.comments: Create an `Event` which fires when a key is pressed
declarations.title: down

declarations.comments: Create an `Event` which fires when a key is released
declarations.title: up

declarations.comments: Create an event which also returns the current pressed keycodes.
declarations.title: withKeys

declarations.comments: Create an `Event` which fires when the mouse moves
declarations.title: move

declarations.comments: Create an event which also returns the current mouse position.
declarations.title: withPosition

declarations.comments: Create an `Event` which fires when a mouse button is pressed
declarations.title: down

declarations.comments: Create an `Event` which fires when a mouse button is released
declarations.title: up

declarations.comments: Create an event which also returns the current mouse buttons.
declarations.title: withButtons

modules.name: FRP.Event.Semantic
modules.comments:
## Denotational Semantics

The goal here is to define a meaning function from `Behavior`s to some semantic
domain in such a way that type class instances pull back from the instances on the
semantic domain, in the sense of
[_type class morphisms_](http://conal.net/papers/type-class-morphisms/).

The implementation of a `Behavior` is polymorphic in the choice of underlying
`Event`. The meaning function is specified with respect to the `Semantic`
event type provided in this module.

We consider behaviors which are valid sampling functions. Precisely, a
`Behavior (Semantic time) a`, which is a function of type

```purescript
b :: forall b. Semantic time (a -> b) -> Semantic time b
```

should preserve the set of input times in the output:

```purescript
map fst (unwrap (b e)) = map fst (unwrap e) :: List time
```

The semantic domain for these behaviors is just the function type

```purescript
time -> a
```

The meaning of the sampling function `b` is then the function

```purescript
\t -> valueOf (sample b (once t id))
```

where

```purescript
valueOf (Semantic (Tuple _ a : Nil)) = a
once t a = Semantic (Tuple t a : Nil)
```

Note that the time-preservation property ensures that the result of
applying `b` is an event consisting of a single time point at time `t`,
so this is indeed a well-defined function.

In addition, we have this property, due to time-preservation:

```
sample b (once t f) = once t (valueOf (sample b (once t f)))
```

### Instances

#### `Functor`

`map` of the meaning is the meaning of `map`:

```
map f (meaning b)
= f <<< meaning b
= \t -> f (valueOf (sample b (once t id)))
  {- parametricity -}
= \t -> valueOf (sample b (map (_ <<< f) (once t id)))
= meaning (map f b)
```

#### `Apply`

`<*>` of the meanings is the meaning of `<*>`:

```
meaning (a <*> b)
= \t -> valueOf (sample (a <*> b) (once t id))
= \t -> valueOf (sample b (sample a (compose <$> once t id)))
= \t -> valueOf (sample b (sample a (once t id)))
= \t -> valueOf (sample b (sample a (once t id)))
  {- sampling preserves times -}
= \t -> valueOf (sample b (once t (valueOf (sample a (once t id))))
= \t -> valueOf (sample b (once t (meaning a t)))
  {- parametricity -}
= \t -> meaning a t (valueOf (sample b (once t id)))
= \t -> meaning a t (meaning b t)
= meaning a <*> meaning b
```

#### `Applicative`

The meaning of `pure` is `pure`:

```
meaning (pure a)
= \t -> valueOf (sample (pure a) (once t id))
= \t -> a
= pure a
```

declarations.comments: The semantic domain for events
declarations.title: Semantic

declarations.comments: Create an event which fires every specified number of milliseconds.
declarations.title: interval

declarations.comments: Create an event which fires every frame (using `requestAnimationFrame`).
declarations.title: animationFrame

declarations.comments: Create an event which reports the current time in milliseconds since the epoch.
declarations.title: withTime
